Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Developing Quantum Nanogeochemistry for Molecular Studies and Inclusive Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports the research of Professor Sara E. Mason at the University of Iowa who will direct a project whose ultimate goal is to develop quantum nanogeochemistry as a platform, (1) to provide fundamental understanding of environmental nanoparticle (ENP) structure-reactivity, (2) to merge distinct theories of ENP reactivity, and, (3) to recruit community college (CC) students for training opportunities at the university level. The research strategy is to carry out Density Functional Theory (DFT)-based simulations on two classes of ENPs: Aqueous aluminum hydroxides modeled as Giant Aluminum Polycations (GAPs) and mineral-water interfaces modeled as Periodic Slab Models (PSMs). Reactivity questions that are suited to each model category are identified, and systematic simulation experiments are designed using comparisons to isolate what controls reactivity. The projects are designed to develop atomistic simulations results of both GAPs and PSMs into new conceptual models for ENP reactivity, a goal that will support or dispel existing theories. For this purpose, the distinctions between the models will be exploited, for example, GAPs are ideal models for tracking reactivity with orbital interactions because they are truly nanoparticulate, and fewer electronic states are expected to participate in interfacial bonding. Also, these aluminum hydroxides do not have d electrons, so they have a less complicated electronic structure than similarly structured iron hydroxides. Meanwhile, the PSM geometry is ideal for probing how adsorption-induced long range bond relaxation and relative energetics can be captured in a Bond Valence (BV) framework. Several of the proposed simulations will involve first time calculations, such as the later described DFT + COSMO (conduction-like screening model)+ (delta)H2O (partial explicit hydration) method for simulating the aqueous Al30 (GAP) and deriving surface-specific Hubbard U corrections to accurately model PSMs comprised of strongly correlated mineral oxides.

The proposed work will enable improved predictions about the sequestration of aqueous contaminants that could ultimately lead to new water remediation strategies. Each research project will support the training of graduate and undergraduate students, and a major emphasis will be placed on the "Never Too Late to Learn" (NTLL) program and its mission to engage community college students in education and research activities that will extend opportunities to train them as the next generation scientists. Efforts to organize research outcomes into DFT databases that will be reported in the associated Data Management Plan, ensure that the fundamental information obtained from the atomistic simulations will be disseminated to the research community, regardless of any failure to pioneer the proposed conceptual models. The unified research and education plans are suited to principal investigator's strengths, background, and commitment to develop quantum nanogeochemistry as a vital field in environmental chemical science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project used computational chemistry to study environmental interfaces of small (nano-scale) aluminum-based clusters and extended mineral surfaces with water and ions. New insights obtained include the unexpected result that nanocluster shape, and not the chemical identity of exposed functional groups, plays a governing role in how ions interact with aqueous clusters. The project also demonstrated that surface effects, such as adsorption-induced strain, prevent empirical, bulk-based predictions from being applicable. Because surfaces can undergo subtle changes in geometry when exposed to water and adsorbates, it is difficult to fully predict how ions will form bonds to surfaces without the full electronic structure description afforded by computational modeling. Our work has shown, though systematic comparisons, that adsorption structures which minimize strain in the adsorbing ion (arsenate) are in general favorable. In strained geometries, even if bond distances are relatively short, the overlap of the electronic states between the surface and the adsorbate are not optimal. This is a direct violation of the expected bulk behavior of bong-length/bond-strength arguments. Methodology developed over the course of the project has provided insights about adequate system size required to model a mineral surface, and how imposing restraints on the geometry can lead to spurious features in the electronic structure. Additionally, we discovered periodic trends in so-called Hubbard U parameters, which can be applied to correlated electrons in mineral oxides to provide more accurate descriptions of electronic structure. Collectively, the project has applied and advanced computational modeling to extract new fundamental understanding of the structure and reactivity of environmental interfaces based on mineral surfaces and metal hydroxide clusters. New considerations of how cluster shape influences the electrostatic potential experienced around the cluster, as well as the role of counter ions in solution, enhance our understanding of chemical processes occurring in environmental waters. The role of directional bonding and strain in mineral-water interface reactivity captured through the modeling further informs how solid phases participate in partitioning reactions with aqueous contaminants. This project has also provided training opportunities for three postdoctoral scholars, and was the chief contribution to the thesis of two female Ph.D. students. An additional Ph.D. is in progress, co-advised with an experimental collaborator. Several undergraduate students were supported, particularly for summer research, and all supported researchers presented results at at least once professional conference or workshop. Additionally, a fourth Ph.D. student, who is also a full-time community college (CC) instructor, has been supported, and has reached candidacy status as of the end of the project. The CC instructor and PI have worked to develop computational chemistry-based laboratory and lecture experiences aimed at first year CC students, utilizing open-source computational packages, with materials disseminated on the PI?s research webpage. The PI has also incorporated lectures on computational geochemistry into advanced courses at the host institution, and contributed a book chapter to a collection of personal accounts aimed at encouraged greater female representation in the sciences. Approximately ten peer reviewed publications have resulted at the time of this report, as well as presentations given by the PI or trainees at conferences spanning disciplines including chemistry, physics, environmental science, and electronic structure methodology.
